posts.sub: I have never once felt the presence of God
posts.com:
I have tried for many years for an experience of something, anything, that would finally allow me to connect with God in any non-zero fashion. I have tried to do this on his own terms. I have read the Bible many times. I have prayed. I have been patient (and continue to be), but so far there has been nothing.

I have tried meditation. I have tried helping people, through volunteer work at the food bank and with various religious organizations.

I have studied ethics and philosophy in my free time.

Even in college, I had a psychedelics phase, which while very interesting and intense, never felt like anything more.

But I have never, once, in my entire life, felt like God was there, or real. I have never had a religious experience of any kind. I have never experienced anything "out of the ordinary."

Every piece of evidence seems to indicate, for years, that there simply is no personal being there at all.

We gather in these generals to discuss our experiences, memories, and connection with Mother Lilith, as well as give other anons who are interested or would like to learn more about Her information or advice.

To the mods: this is NOT a /succgen/, this is NOT a spirit love thread. Nothing about this thread or topic is inherently sexual in any way, shape, or form. Lilith represents many many many more qualities other than sex, and that's one of the things that us as her Chosen are trying to get out into the open. She is wisdom, intelligence, strength, love, peace. Sexuality is but one small part of who she is.

Last thread: >>33670486

P.S. Do you appreciate Lilith, and wish to chat with others who feel likewise? To take inspiration and find new ways to express your appreciation? Or perhaps to ask questions, and learn from open-minded people what Lilith can mean for you?

Or are you looking for a server with a less informal vibe? To be guided safely to establish contact with Lilith? Then also consider joining Magus' server, the Children of Lilith: discord dot gg/jpXwcQ7tUF

>Wasn't that Satan though?
No. Who is Satan, anyway, exactly?

>Feel free to suggest resources
Resources:
Books:
- Liber Lilith by Donald Tyberson
A Gnostic Grimoire and Novel
https://www.pdfdrive.com/liber-lilith-a-gnostic-grimoire-e185231845.html
- Embracing Lilith by Mark H Williams
No PDF available online, but it's worth the price of admission. Split into three sections, it covers accounts of working with the Goddess and her place in history, a fictional account of her origins written from her perspective, and a Grimoire.
- Lilith: Dark Feminine Archetype by Asenath Mason
https://pdfcoffee.com/lilith-dark-feminine-archetype-2-pdf-free.html
This one is a collection of writings by various peoples, with a brief but fairly thorough history at the beginning. Part grimoire, part reverence. Contains art and accounts by different people.

Videos:
Who is Lilith? Ancient Origins by Esoterica
https://youtu.be/n1EKccz4fS0
A fairly extensive history on her historical origins
The Untold Truth of Lilith by Grunge
https://youtu.be/01guwJbp_ug
A short video intended for a popular audience
Goes over her myth and general nature
Goddess Lilith - What she likes, how to contact
https://youtu.be/75bnMRPRiDk
A simple, short to the point video that rings true to my experiences.
My Experiences Workiing with Lilith
https://youtu.be/EHol9LrpWks
One woman's account of her experience

But since then, my life began to change drastically, and I found relief that I didn't even think was possible.

As the wish I'd once made reached a satisfactory conclusion, and Lilith offered to guide me towards a new purpose, I thanked her and began to show my appreciation for her more. I thought I accepted myself now that I'm finally at peace with my body, only to feel lost again as spiritual experiences confront me with all sorts of sides of myself that I don't know how to reconcile. I'd have been content to ignore them for the rest of my life, but now I'm unsure how I'm supposed to proceed anymore. And although I recall her offer to guide me, I'm reluctant as I fear I'll be forced to face even more.

That's what I get for being dishonest with myself; for being so easily seduced as my contradictions are exposed.

>>33737944
I always struggled to relate to transgender people. Dysphoria was primarily a physical thing for me that ceased after my surgery, so I find the focus on stereotypes asinine and childish.

Two years ago, my older brother asked me to strangle his neck as hard as I can. He was curious if his neck muscles are stronger than my arms. I refused as it made me uncomfortable.
A year later, I felt scared as I realised how weak I am physically. But when I told my fiancé that I wanted to try building abs to boost my confidence, he was against it; he said he dislikes muscles on women. I lost motivation, as I realised I can never be as strong as him anyway.

I dislike alcohol, but knowing I'm way too hard on myself, I drank half a glass of champagne yesterday, hoping it would loosen me up a bit. The results were as agonising as I expected. It was far too little for me to lose control, but it became slightly harder for me to suppress my unwanted emotions. As they raged inside of me, I snuck away from my family and isolated myself. I forced myself to remain silent and still, but the storm inside only worsened.

When I returned, my brother noticed I was tense. He said to let out my anger by hugging him as hard as I can. So I embraced him, as if trying to crush him.
In that moment, I felt glad I'm physically weak. "I don't have to hold back. I don't have be afraid I'll hurt others, if this is all I can do", I thought.
But then, he said repeatedly: "You're strong. Those hormones didn't affect you nearly as badly as I thought." He sounded so relieved.

My brother is the strongest man I know. If I can be strong in his eyes even without training after 7 years of having less testosterone than most women, then I shouldn't belittle myself.
So I've decided to start working out and learn martial arts. It doesn't matter if I won't be as strong as I'd have been as a man; transitioning gave me other things that are more important to me. Even so, I still want to become my best self.

I attempted physical transmutation a few years ago, as I was curious whether it might work. However, I discontinued my efforts after a few weeks, as it caused severe inflammation and pieces of dead skin falling off in a particular area. Not only was the pain becoming unbearable, but I realised what I was doing was highly dangerous, as it was becoming difficult to even urinate. After discontinuing my magick, which consisted of daily energy work in a deep trance, the symptoms subsided in just a day.

My conclusions are that it's far more efficient to change physical things by physical means, and spiritual things by spiritual means. Not only that, but it's dangerous to attempt to remove body parts with magick; it's no different from convincing those parts of your body to destroy themselves, with no guarantee of actually getting the results you want. In my experience, physical surgery is both safer and much less painful in comparison. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33715218
I'm pretty sure I died once. I was working construction briefly in my early 20's, and one day I was on some scaffolding. Anyway, some of the scaffolding was uneven and I tripped, falling off the side, approximately 30 feet towards a pile of breeze blocks collected in a pile on the ground below. The last thing I remember is putting my hands out and shutting my eyes closed just before I made impact with the ground. I kept my eyes closed, but this impact never came, so I opened my eyes and I was laying back down on the top level of the scaffolding again. Some of my work colleagues came over and asked me what happened, and I could only say I'm not sure. They later said I just tripped and fell, but just straight down, rather than over the edge as I remember. But this DID happen. I remember in that split second of falling, knowing I was about to smash into those breeze blocks face first and die. I remember the terror, the fear. I still had that fear even when I woke up and was OK. It actually affected me so greatly that I immediately quit construction as a career.

And yeah, I went over two sentences. Sue me.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33744163
Look up the case of Christopher Knight, AKA 'the North Pond Hermit.' He lived innawoods for 25 years before being caught. He was up on charges of stealing since he'd steal the bare minimum of the bare essentials from nearby homes and homesteads. You may want to learn from his mistakes and mimick his successes.

A few things to consider:
1. Knight never lit a fire. This helped him escape detection.
2. Beware of thermal camera drones, I wouldn't be surprised if civilian ones are used to track down isolated camps on public land. Hadjis in the middle east combated these with thick wool blankets.
3. Read books on survivalism and watch YouTube about it. Understand what you're taking on and whether being homeless in a big city, with all its attendant dangers and degradations, might not be a safer option for you.
4. At minimum get yourself a long-life portable water filter such as a katadyn. Splash out here if nowhere else. Water borne disease will rape you dead.
5. You may want to have a portable camp or multiple spots you move between in an irregular fashion.
6. If you're going to plant forest gardens be prepared to defend them from wildlife, especially deer. They are bad enough for settled farmers much less hermits and will destroy an entire acre of crops in a night, if not more.

>Learn how to fish
You'll need to be near water anyways, God knows you can't build a well on other people's property. Learn how to make nets, this means learning how to make knots. Since you're poor, you'll have to study plants in your area that are good for making cord/rope. Making traps, digging inlets, preserving said fish through smoking or salting

>Botony
You will absolutely need to know what plants you can or cannot eat. What times of year they are edible and the ability to preserve them.

>Wild game
You will need to hunt, traps/snares/projectiles. Knowing knots and how to make cord from plants will be invaluable here. Learning different snares for small game, maybe buy a few bear traps if you can. You will need to stockpile food, salting and smoking meat will be essential.

>Shelter
You will fucking die if exposure in most parts of the world without proper shelter. Again, knowing how to make knots and cord is invaluable. Knowing the right plants, clays, rocks to use to make waterproof shelter. This is not easy, it's not a fucking joke.

>Water
Just stay near a fucking body of water, don't be stupid anon, you can easily become dehydrated in half a day. In the middle of nowhere, which brings me to my next point

>Navigation
Know your surroundings, study maps, bring maps, make your own maps, learn landmarks, never stray to far from home base.

>Wildlife
Pray you don't get attacked by a large cat or bear, you will probably die. Try and bring a gun that shoots high caliber rounds like a rifle and have like 50 boxes of ammo. Know proper gun safety, don't be a fucking idiot.

You will only have leisure time in the winter, when it's too cold to really do anything else. That is if you stockpiled enough wood, you ll still probably be constantly looking for wood to burn. This dark, cold, lonely time in the wilderness during the winter can easily break your psyche. You must be extremely strong willed and smart to survive by yourself.

>>33753426
Not all imaginations respond the same and you won't respond the same every day to every technique either.
Try writing a story about the ladder, some kind of "narrative", even if it's a few lines long, and flesh out characters or something. Really put emotion into every piece.
I find that starting with something more personal or with feelings I know can really help visualization. For instance, if I wanted to visualize climbing something I would first pick up a stick in real life and squeeze it hard to get the tactile sensation, put some kind of emotion to my doing of that action, then use it when visualizing. I already have a base to go off so even if there's distractions I can think back to that one time I was squeezing the stick and have a clear picture and feel of how it is to climb something by the tactile sense of my hand being filled like that. It's like you thinking back to when you took a warm shower or the feeling of walking or something, easy to do for something you've done.

>>33751242
>How do I create a "real challenge simulation room"?
You have to research Persistent Worlds in dreams first, you can't just go and create whatever you want, you need to learn the basics and create something simple that becomes permanent, then transform that into your simulation room.
Have you ever had recurring dreams? You always go back to the same places and do the same things. Those places exist somewhere and you can visit them, if you can do it in purpose you can turne them into your challenge room.
Then you start setting up your rules on that room, your body can sustain damage and next time you dream about it you feel the injuries and consequences of previous times, your body can only do what you could do in real time, as you improve the room becomes more challenging and you can do harder things in it, and there's more at stake if you fail, etc.
Waking up with scars from your dreams is also possible, I've known people that dream of being scratched and wake up with the scratches, and show them to me, though, it's something unwanted, you can control it,approach your goal in lucid dreaming, become better at them, and create your room when you're ready.

Live to the end and rewind the movie. 20 years from now you can remember that at some point your wish fulfilled. Rewind more until you remember how you felt right after the wish fulfilled. Rewind more, and remember how it felt when the wish was fulfilled. Rewind more to the point you knew it was about to fulfill. Rewind more to the point you knew it would fulfill soon.
Compare the feeling you had when you knew to the feeling you had when you didn't know.
Realize it was the knowing that it would fulfill that caused it to fulfill.
What you need to fix is that difference, you currently believe that there's an unknown line in your life that you will live and you don't know if it contains your wish fulfilled, but you already went to the future and saw that it fulfilled in the past, so you know it got fulfilled.
How do you know for certain? How do you know for certain the sun will come up tomorrow? You don't, maybe the earth stands still and it never does, or a black hole eats the earth and there's never a tomorrow.
You just ASSUME the sun will come up tomorrow, that's what you do with your wish, you no longer worry about it because you know it's coming, and the doubts disappear.

Back then you could assume an intelligent person knew about some of the different scams and schemes, and less intelligent people may or may not suspect them. Internet let everyone know about the basic details of all the scams and schemes, but now they actively split them up into conspiracy theories they believe (typical normies believe in any theories about a white hive-mind and white secret societies that create privilege) and conspiracy theories they don't believe (typical normies don't believe in any specific criminal or occult elements unless they're linked in with the white privilege complex). And just lately we've seen people go from being suspicious of big pharma (100% confirmed to have deliberately and consciously caused the opioid crisis, for one thing) to deciding they cannot possibly do anything wrong.

Back in the pre-Internet era, normies would believe any claim about conspiracies run by (for example) Soviet Russia, or Red China, or Islamic Terrorists, but similar things were impossible in their own country.

There are no 'specifics.' If you imagine the setup described that's it.
Sometimes they have a display for the person to focus on with EEG data but that's not actually useful for focusing in some slick hollywood way like you allude to. That's fluff bullshit they slip in the books to make the whole thing sexier than it was.

The EEG is literally for you to focus on, that's it. Same as the random number string in group exercises, it's a common string each person has in mind but it doesn't mean a thing.
The only part of the setup that is technically 'necessary' is EMI headphones since the Monroe tapes are designed for that. But again that's obvious once you know you're using those tapes.

Nobody is "focusing" on some kind of monitor showing how "snychronized" they were becoming. You try to get out of body using basic instinctive physical motions while in the hypnogogic state.
The maneuvers are described as "rolling out" or "standing up like a telephone pole."

People lie flat on their backs, space out and try to use one of the exit maneuvers to achieve out of body. If they pulled it off their consciousness would squirt out like a tube of toothpaste and if not they'd get a jolt as they stop themselves from actually rolling off the table. Not so sexy.

Gateway was the 1970s and all they did was establish theta peaks for individuals, it wasn't a part of the process to do anything but recording that data. They tried to use it for more than that but it was not reliable or nearly useful enough to warrant developing hardware just for the job. Any work done was with normal medical monitors.

Theta waves are just an abstract metric for "focus" and it's not that useful which is why you see it referenced sparingly. It's more useful as a diagnostic tool for figuring out how psychic people are, not a realtime monitoring tool.

The maharishi effect is *absolutely* a hard, measurable expression of the consciousness field. It's basically EM; it follows the inverse square law of falloff. We need to study this.

Why is resonance and density so important in ancient ceremonial sites? Is it possible to shape consciousness using sound, music perhaps? Well of course it is, that's what this is all about. posts.name: Anonymous

>>33734574
Medicine is pretty different from most other fields in that as long as you loosely observe the Maxim (least possible harm with maximum benefit) you can do pretty unusual things as long as the patient consents. This allows you to form a hypothesis, perform a study and publish those conclusive findings without interference.

In other fields, you'd publish your findings with the assumption others will replicate your study. Depending on the resources available, this process can be used to sequester certain topics. You have lots of examples of this in fuel and energy technology.

Medicine doesn't operate with the same attitude towards experimentation-- experiments do not often yield conclusive results in the context of their study so when they do, it's taken more seriously. Humans cannot be 'controls' since every body is so different, thus arguments about test conditions tend to be secondary criticisms.

Consider; you are designing a reentry capsule. The object must survive the forces of reentry. The capsule represents the psychoenergetics problem. You must get the problem down to earth without breaking it apart into a thousand pieces.
Imagine psychic research is thermodynamics. Spirituality is the aerodynamics.

The problem we have today is to design a psychoenergetics approach without overlapping spiritual science (which we simply don't understand as well.) Does this mean we have to exclude spirituality? No. It just means our solution cannot directly define things about spirituality we don't know. So to create our vehicle we setup a hypersonic wind tunnel and start testing various shapes. This is absolutely changing its aerodynamics, but all we're measuring is thermal energy. Aerodynamics doesn't matter because we can still understand aerodynamics through thermodynamics in this situation.

Pyschoenergetics is the same. It certainly involves spiritual mysticism, but to get the concepts to the ground we need to look at the things we can measure first even if we miss the whole picture. Once that's done the spiritual side may even become easier to understand.

>>33748589
yeah, this. also, each day/month/year is continually growing shorter in relation to your total time spent on this earth.
one year for a two year old is 50% of their life, but one year for a twenty year old is 5% of their life.
let yourself be bored more often, or do things that move you away from your routine.
if you do the same thing every day, then it's obvious that at some point they'll melt together and an entire year can feel like one very long, blurry day.
you don't have to adopt the "yolo live every day like its your last" mindset and go to the extremes of literally living each day differently, but you could break your time into chunks, if that makes sense.
so, for me, something that helps me "slow down" my clock is by breaking things up into the seasons. in the spring, i spend a lot of time preparing my garden.
during summer, i spend a lot of time outside both enjoying my garden and tending to it. i also spend a lot of time 'experiencing the world' by going camping, on bike rides, walks at night
in the autumn, i start to harvest the majority of what i've planted (lots of smaller things get harvested throughout the year), then i start cleaning everything and putting it into compost.
then, i use winter as a time to hunker down and reflect.

basically, enrich your life with more variety but also give yourself time to be bored and do nothing. then you'll actually enjoy the mundane and it won't morph itself into some weird caricature.

Time is not moving faster. What's happening is that our culture is stagnating.

The way you tell time is by observing changes in your environment. If the environment changes a lot then you feel a lot of time has passed but if your environment changes little then you feel no time has passed at all.
Our culture is stagnating so even though it's been a decade it feels like a year has passed.
But culture is really just one facet of this phenomena. Everything is stagnating. The future is gone, replaced by an endless regurgitation of shitty remixes of the past.

She had committed suicide by cyanide poisoning. The name and address she used to check into the hotel turned out to be fake, and her true identity has never been determined.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In the early morning hours of March 18th, 1990, two men disguised as police officers convinced a security guard at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston to let them inside, under the guise of responding to a disturbance call in the museum's courtyard. The guard, along with the only other security guard on duty that night, were quickly handcuffed, bound, and locked in the museum's basement. The thieves then spent over an hour taking thirteen priceless works of art from the museum, including "The Concert", a painting by the Dutch artist Johannes Vermeer, which is considered by some to be the most valuable stolen object in the world. The thieves were never caught; however in 2013, the FBI announced that they knew the identities of the two criminals, but that they were already deceased. None of the art has ever been found, and no one was ever arrested.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
On an icy Friday in January of 1956, six-year old Susan Cadieux was playing with her older brothers and a friend at a playground not far from her home in London, Ontario. At approximately 7:45 PM, a man approached Susan, and claimed that he had something to give her. He then told the other children that he was meeting with a priest at a church, and that he lived on York Street (although he pointed towards King Street). When Susan had not returned by 8 PM, her brothers told their parents, who then contacted police. By 1:30 AM, around 300 people had joined the search.
The following morning, at about 10 AM, Susan's body was found in a nearby warehouse. She had been sexually assaulted, and her cause of death was listed as exposure. It is believed she died less than 3 hours before being found.

Tears were frozen to her face.

Her killer was never apprehended.

posts.com: On August 23rd, 1912, 4-year old Bobby Dunbar disappeared while fishing near a swamp in St. Landry Parish, Louisiana. Eight months later, William Cantwell Walters, a handyman, was arrested for his kidnapping. Walters, however, claimed the boy he had with him was not Bobby Dunbar, but actually Bruce Anderson, the son of a woman who worked for his (Walters') family. Still, the boy was returned to Lessie and Percy Dunbar (Bobby's parents), who claimed it was in fact their son. The boy would then spend the rest of his life as Bobby Dunbar, dying in 1966 in his late 50s. In 2004, DNA testing was done, which confirmed the worst: The boy who had returned and spent most of his life with the Dunbars was in fact, NOT Bobby Dunbar. The real Bobby Dunbar was never found. It is believed he may have drowned or been eaten by an alligator during the fishing trip.

posts.com: 6 people were killed between 1918 and 1919 in New Orleans by an assailant known only as the Axeman of New Orleans. In a famous letter supposedly written by the Axeman, he claimed to be demon rather than human, and very fond of jazz music. In the letter, the writer spoke of his plan to kill in the early morning of March 19th, 1919, but any house playing jazz music would be spared. No murders were committed that night.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In January of 1947, a young woman by the name of Elizabeth Short was found brutally murdered in Los Angeles. The 22 year old's body had been cleanly severed in half at the waist, and her intestines were neatly tucked under her backside. Her legs had been spread, her elbows bent upwards, and her hands positioned gracefully above her head, not unlike like those of a ballet dancer. Her face had been carved from the corners of her mouth, all the way up to her ears, forming a scar commonly known as a Glasgow smile. In the decades since, Short has become one of the most famous murder victims in American history. Her murder came less than a year after the release of a famous murder-mystery film starring Alan Ladd, which may well be how Short came to be known as the Black Dahlia. Her killer has never been identified.

posts.com: 4 year old Michael Dunahee disappeared from a playground in Canada in 1991, just meters away from his parents. His disappearance resulted in one of the largest investigations in Canadian history, but he has never been found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Capitol Hill's mystery soda machine was a Coke-themed vending machine in Capitol Hill, Seattle that was in operation from at least the early 1990s until its disappearance in 2018.It is unknown who stocked the machine.

A drink could be chosen using one of the "? mystery ?" buttons and the dispensed drinks were rare cans that were either ordinarily unavailable in the United States or had not been in circulation since the 1980s. Examples of the beverages were Mountain Dew White Out, a raspberry-flavored Nestea Brisk, a Hawaiian Punch, and a Grape Fanta. It was rumored that Vanilla Coke, Black Cherry Frescas, and Sunkist Cherry Limeade were also available. The owner of the business closest to the machine, a locksmith, claimed to have no knowledge of who operated it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Rebecca Coraim was last seen on a Disney Cruise ship where she worked. Security camera footage shows her having a seemingly stressful phone conversation with an unknown person. She then walks off camera, and is never seen again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: From the late 1970s until as recently as the early 1990s, as many as 11 women were murdered in a series of killings that is now known as the Redhead Murders. The killer(s), as well as many of the victims, have never been identified.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Starting in 1972, at least 7 young women were killed by an unknown assailant by various means, including strangulation and poisoning. The perpetrator(s) were never apprehended, though some believe the murders may have been the work of the Zodiac Killer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Three women, aged 18, 19, and 47, disappeared from a home in Springfield, Missouri at some point during the early morning hours of June 7th, 1992. Their house showed no signs of violence (except for a shattered glass lamp globe), their belongings were untouched, their cars were still in the driveway, and the family dog was inside the house, unharmed. No trace of the women has ever been found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: On December 13th, 2009, Steven Koecher parked his car outside of a retirement home in Henderson, Nevada, 150 miles from his own home in St. George, Utah. His reasons for being in Nevada have never been fully determined, and he has not been seen since. At the time of his disappearance, Koecher was behind on his rent. Several years later, his landlord was arrested on drug charges. Some believe that Koecher had been running drugs for his landlord, and was killed in a drug-deal gone wrong.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: 25 year old Tiffany Daniels disappeared near a beach in Pensacola, Florida in 2013. Despite several sightings, she has never been found. Her family believe she may have been the victim of human trafficking.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In September 2013, unemployed drug addict Tiffany Whitton fled from a Wal-mart store after being accused of shoplifting, never to be seen again. Her case received significantly less media attention when compared to other young, white women who had disappeared, likely due to her troubled past and criminal lifestyle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: On June 16th, 1990, 52 year old Trevaline Evans left a note on the door of the antique shop she owned which said "Back in 2 minutes". Over 30 years later, she still hasn't returned.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In 1912, eight people were found dead in a home in Iowa. They had all been brutally bludgeoned to death with an axe. Despite a long investigation with several suspects, no one was ever charged.

posts.com: Genghis Khan ruled what was once the largest empire in history. Before he died, he requested that he be buried in an unmarked grave. Several legends exist regarding his burial. Some say that several thousands of slaves and guards carried his casket to his final resting place, then were killed or committed suicide in order to hide the location. Others believe that a river was diverted over the ground where he was buried. Either way, almost 800 years later, the location of the tomb of Genghis Khan remains a mystery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
On February 28, 1983, a pair of looters entered an abandoned apartment building in St. Louis, Missouri. Upon lighting up a cigarette in the darkness, the two criminals were shocked to discover the headless body of a young girl, her hands bound with rope, and wearing only a yellow sweater.
To this day, St. Louis Jane Doe has not been identified. A crucial piece of evidence, the sweater she was found wearing, was lost after detectives mailed it to a psychic in Florida. The case has since gone cold.
Her head was never found.

Five teenagers disappeared near Clinton Avenue in August 1978. Philander Hampton, a local in police custody for an unrelated crime, claimed that he had killed the five in a house fire after they stole his marijuana. He pleaded guilty in 2011 and was released in 2017.

posts.com: A Roman dodecahedron or Gallo-Roman dodecahedron is a small hollow object made of copper alloy which has been cast into a regular dodecahedral shape: twelve flat pentagonal faces, each face having a circular hole of varying diameter in the middle, the holes connecting to the hollow center. Roman dodecahedra date from the 2nd to 4th centuries AD and their purpose remains a mystery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In 1984, a naked female torso was found floating in the Spokane River in Washington. The hands, feet, and head were all missing. 14 years later, a human skull was found at the bottom of an embankment, also in Spokane. It was later determined that the head belonged to the same woman as the torso found over a decade earlier. The woman's identity, and the identity of her killer, has never been determined.
After the head was found, detective Don Geise was assigned to transport it to a forensic anthropologist in western Washington. His fifth grade daughter, accompanying him on this trip, insisted that the unidentified woman needed a name. She decided upon the name "Millie", which is what the victim is still called to this day.

posts.com:
In Labette County, Kansas during the timespan of 1872-1873 a family of serial killers known as the Blood Benders (consisting of a father, mother, son and daughter) who spoke German, killed at least 20 people. They would lure people into the breakfast and bed inn, seat them at a table and have one of the men (who would be hiding behind a curtain) would hit them in the back of the head with a hammer. One of the women would then slit the throat for good measure and then dump the body in a nearby trapdoor.
After being questioned about the disappearance of a person who recently went in the direction of their inn, they quickly left with all of their food and personal belongings via their wagon.
They were tracked to the New Mexico Territory but were not pursued.
There are many stories about what happened to them and even some arrests of the women, but many doubt the authenticity of the stories and the identity of those arrested.

As well as being a fucked up junkie, there's a lot of shame involved that kept me from contacting anyone I knew. It took a while just for my head to clear and realize I was free, anyway. Talking about it online is one thing, telling people I knew is totally different. As for being a liability? I have no idea what to say. I was in bedrooms and living rooms with people. posts.com: this dude, Shane Fell, used to run a Minecraft server I played on back in 2011. He was driving home at night when he lost control of his car, causing it to flip. He phoned his brother twice - the first time asking for him to come to the scene, where he would be waiting, seemingly shaken but indicating he wasn't injured. He phoned again a few minutes later confirming the brother was en route. His brother arrived at the wreck, and Shane was gone. This was in a relatively populated area of Louisiana, with not much wilderness or anything for him to disappear into, aside from a small canal, which was searched. There have been reports of a couple sighings of Shane amongst the transients in the area, but nothing has been confirmed.

A lot of people focus on where she went (and rightfully so), but I think an even bigger mystery is why did she leave in the first place? The family had no internet connection, the FBI investigated and there were no reports of any grooming, she had no family problems to run away from, so why did she just up and leave?
A thought that I had (it's just a thought, I'm not saying it's correct), is that her disappearance may have been part of some sort of "game". The day she disappeared, February 14th, wasn't just Valentine's Day. It was also her parent's wedding anniversary. What if she planned some kind of surprise for them? Some kind of Gone Girl-esque scavenger hunt, and while she was setting it up, something went horribly wrong.
Again, I'm not saying it's correct, or even likely. It's just something to think about. I know when I was 9 years old, I would have loved doing something like that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It really depends on who you are.

Some people are born or raised in such a way that they have a clean mind and few psychological problems. For them it's easy to focus and direct their mind.

Others (like how I used to be) literally live in their mind all day long, they daydream a lot and their thoughts literally control their actions and how they feel, and the worst is that they don't even realize it because they've been living like this for so long.

So I'd suggest that you just sit and observe, just sit and don't chase anything because you may be just chasing goals which are not achievable or you might be running away from harsh truths which you must first face and endure before you can move on to greater things.

Your mind is NOT you, this was a hard pill for me to take, all those thoughts which sound 100% true are just fabrications of a wild mind.

So yeah, just sit and watch, watch how your mind goes running around but don't follow it, nor make stories about it, don't try anything for there is nothing to try, just sit, your mind will come up with all crazy stuff and you will just sit there and watch it BUT without thinking "Oh I'm watching now, I'm meditating so good" for that is also thinking.

Just be the observer, and yes, with time your mind will calm down and you will be left alone or with very few thoughts, then the real "You" will start becoming clearer and that's when you can direct your focus on APing, chakras/whatever, subconscious, old forgotten memories and other things.
But you gotta first sit in silence, sit without trying to do anything. Just observe.

posts.com:
I've been meditating for years now and yet I can't really put into words what meditation is, I like the "meditation is deliberate focus of awareness" thing that people usually talk about.

Cultivating the ability to focus takes time. Focusing on the breath or a candle are the 2 basic exercises people recommend, it teaches you to "feel" and "observe" which are different from "thinking", it may take months to snap out of the "thinking" mode for just a second but that sole second is enough to show you that your thinking mind is not you nor your reality, it's like a radio which plays all the time and you were living with that radio open for most of your life.

>>33699233
For me the "observer" focus/mode is when you are not a slave to your thoughts and you are calmer thus you don't get dragged away by them, while the "focus" focus is the ability to focus on one thing with all your might, I say that those 2 go hand-in-hand and maybe someone could say that they are the same thing: the ability to take a step back from everything, be calm and direct your focus/observing whatever you want.

Also during my sits I remember how to feel my feelings. Feelings inhabit your body and you can feel them better if you focus on them, they usually carry forgotten memories or various insights and blissful states if you focus on them enough.

Meditation is a paradox to me, it's like a means to an end but also the end itself, it's like a vehicle which takes you places but also it's just erasing all the unnecessary noise around you to realize that all those places were always here next to you.

So sit and watch your breath, feel your body breathing, your mind will make thousands of stories about anything but just let it be, don't even label those thoughts, don't even say "I'm letting them go", just let them be and focus on your breath, on the feeling of your body breathing, your mind will say "that's stupid, analyzing these important things is better", but just focus on the breath.

>>33710828
What you say makes sense but from my own experiences I 'd say that those 2 are the same thing.

Focusing is like an ability, people are good at it or not.

You can be focused on just this moment and your surroundings without being focused on a single object. This is like being totally present, you are focused on the present, your mind isn't wandering outside of your control, thoughts may pop up but they don't take you away in daydreaming (which most people have but don't realize). Imagine that this focusing ability is like a magnifying glass, let's say that what I just described is the point "zero" of the magnifying glass, our basic reality. This is what you called the "observer" mode.

However you can zoom into one single thing using that magnifying glass, say your breath or an object. You can literally move your entire consciousness towards that thing to the point that your awareness travels there, some people say that "wizards/shamans/yogis" can move their entire consciousness towards that object and move it with their will or inhabit the body of an animal, others say that they can zoom their eyesight so much to the point that they look at the atoms of an object, some even say that they hypnotize others through this way. This is the point "1" of the glass.

Conversely you can even zoom out, you can become the whole room and even look at yourself from above, you can become your whole house and the whole city, you can focus on the whole galaxy and the whole cosmos, you can even break the linear time illusion and realize that everything is one single moment which takes place here and now. Let's say that this is the point "-1" of the glass.

That's what meditation is: Realizing that you are everything at the same time, your awareness can go everywhere since you are part of the whole, the ego is an illusion, break free from it and realize that you are whole, ignore your thoughts which most of the time are just the ego talking nonsense.

>>33699233
This post made me want to share something semi-related - an experience of mine:

For years I always wondered if non-directive meditation is the same as directive meditation, or if one was better than the other or even the "correct way to meditate".

In the non-directive kind you just sit and be aware, if something pops up you just watch it until it goes away without making stories in your mind about it.

In the directive aka focus meditation you focus on a single object and you stay with it, if something else pops up you immediately return to the object.

After practicing both for a long time I can say one thing: They both have the same result which is your thinking mind eventually quieting down, the thoughts become less and less and you are left in silence and that's when the real fun begins.

(continued in the next post)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33726002
(cont.)

I could say that non-directive would be better suited for advanced practitioners who can manage their thoughts better and are better at not being dragged away from their wandering mind, those are the practitioners who are more grounded, whose their breath is 24/7 calm. That's the "observer focus" you are talking about.

Directive is better for people who are new to meditation, those people are usually overthinkers, their breath patterns are all over the place, I'd suggest that someone who begins meditation focuses on his belly expanding or his chest or on the feeling the air makes in his throat. I suggest this because in an overthinking beginner the thoughts are coming at a very fast and strong rate. Imagine this kind of meditation like you holding on a steel pole with all your might so the tornado (thoughts) won't drag you away. That's the "focusing focus" you talked about.

So it all comes down to having a calm mind, and sitting will do this anyway, sit in the dark with no sound or anything to bother you and the thoughts WILL stop, what really helps is if you also incorporate breathwork and physical exercise in your everyday life and if you reduce screen usage (which fills your mind with lots of information), these will help you reach the "no-thought" state faster.

I remember sitting down to do "Focus on breath" meditation and various memories and bad feelings popped up, I ignored them and returned to the breath, then thoughts like "You are ignoring what's important!" popped up and I became anxious that I was using meditation to run away from my problems but I knew that I wasn't really doing that and that was just my overthinking mind not wanting to stop. Most of our problems are just thoughts in our minds and are not real at all.

So just sit and focus on the breath or on the moment, or on your body, don't think too much about it, thoughts and words are not everything, feeling is also important, feeling this moment here now.

>>33700019
Start with objects that are in another room from where you are. Then move on to physical settings in the house, imagine whole rooms and whole layouts of the house. Next, move to things that are outdoors like a park, a lake, forest or other natural settings of the sort. After that move to more dynamic situations like a busy city center, a school campus between classes when there's a lot of people walking everywhere, a busy restaurant, etc. After than imagine scenarios with yourself and other people who are immediately with you where you give each person unique physical attributes, personality traits and have them say the certain things you want them to say.

Literally that simple. Should take you sometime.

>>33732995
Shut off your PC monitor, close your laptop, back away from the desk.

Sit up right but remain in a relaxed position. Close your eyes. Take a deep breath through your nose and feel as the air travels down through your lungs and you expand your belly to fullness. Holy for 3 seconds, then slowly exhale through your pursed lips. Repeat twice more. Feel relaxed and just let your thoughts flow. Don't get in their way, just let them happen, sit back and observe. Keep breathing normally through your nose and continue to let your thoughts happen, sit back and observe them. Do this for the next 5 minutes.

There. You've done mindfulness meditation and you are going to feel better after the 5 minutes are up. Do this for the next few weeks and write down any worries, anxieties, intrusive thoughts, or recurring themes that run through your mind while meditating.

That's literally all you have to know right now. Meditation is one of those things that are better of just experiencing from the get got instead of reading about them. You can do body scan meditations, mantra meditations, visualization meditation and KUNDALINI BRO later. No need to complicate things.

Keep reading and lurking the thread for resources.

I'm pretty sure that there are people in here who are super good at controlling their minds and they can AP on demand and other stuff but let me give some advice to the average Joe:

Just be, that's the meditative state, be and focus on yourself right here right now, feel yourself living here now, don't add things to it, be truthful about what you're living right now, lies may be comforting but they never work in the long run, be truthful about yourself even if the truth hurts a but (It won't hurt later).
Yes thoughts may come, bad memories may come, yes you may feel bad for not being free of them, watch all that process, it's there for a reason, love what you have inside of you for it's your gift.

>>33744644
I'm the same anon who said that quitting coffee helps, I'm here with new things you can consider:

- Maybe your volition is not that strong? Maybe you just sit and you hope that something happens? Maybe instead of trying to focus on your breath you half-ass it and your mind takes you over all the time? You have taken notice that you are indeed mind wandering, you have taken the first step of observing this - a step which many humans never take in their whole life - so why you don't act? Why your mind keeps on being the leader?

- Maybe your thoughts seem like they are extremely important and you can't ignore them? If yes then write them down after each session and really ask yourself: Is this important now? Most of the time it isn't, it's most likely a past semi-traumatic event which keeps on repeating in your head, or a worry about the future, ignore them both, the now is the most important thing.

- Maybe you are trying to focus on your breath through your thinking mind? That's too narrow, try to FEEL, like literally feel your whole body breathing, the breath fills your lungs only but it also moves your belly and your pelvic floor with its movements, your shoulder blades and clavicle may also move during inhalation/exhalation, feel your whole body sitting there and breathing.

- Speaking of the body, try to keep your head retracted (search about this head posture), also imagine a thread which is attached in the middle of your head pulling it lightly up, this head position helps with sleepiness.

- Again: Don't make a story about it, it's just you breathing, yes you will just sit there and feel yourself breathing, your mind will think "What? Only that? That's too simple/stupid/whatever", but believe me: first achieving calmness and silence is the most important thing.

- And last: Coffee is not the only thing which may hinder your meditation practice, everyday cannabis smoking or regular pills may hinder it too.

>>33744644
Everyone is saying that you should focus on your breath and maybe it works for some people but I will speak about my own experience: I was trying for years to concentrate just like you and I just couldn't, then I decided to just sit and accept in silence without trying to fight or force anything nor direct my focus 100% on something, just observe myself in silence.

I did that because I knew that I had unresolved childhood trauma inside of me, I was full of anger and anxiety most of the day and even during meditation, it was like a huge alarm which was ringing for years now and I wasn't doing anything about it.

This way of meditating did indeed have some kind of focus but it was more of a calm, "sit back and relax" kind of focus in which I was just being aware of everything that came, some people call this "transcendental meditation" or "mindfulness" I think.

So you could say that my object of meditation was my thoughts which were usually various past experiences which I had the tendency to remember all the time or even made-up scenarios. Nearly all of those thoughts carried hateful feelings with them and my mind wanted to live out those scenarios which they usually ended up in me beating up someone who had mistreated me, I had violence and hate inside of me (all from my abusive childhood).

However as I said before in my meditations I didn't sit to fight or force things but I sought to observe in silence, so every time this pull came, this pull towards violence - this pull towards making more thoughts and extending the scenario - I choose instead to just sit, and what I saw was fear that the other person was mistreating me and I wasn't doing anything, this feeling of fear was so strong which was almost unbearable and it took me many meditations to finally resolve it.

So as >>33744852 said, yeah I was probably using meditation as a way to escape those alarming feelings of hate and fear.

Maybe something similar is happening to you? Who knows.

Just sitting and watching, my mind/ego wanted to make scenarios e.t.c. but I just sat there and took all the thoughts along with the feelings that came with them AND I didn't give into the temptation of making those hateful scenarios in which I "rebelled against those who maltreated me".

So yeah, it's all inside of you, just give it time and practice often, don't aspire to be wizard/yogi/superman or anything, be a loving person first - especially towards yourself. Most people want to become strong because they can't accept their weak side but the irony is that true strength lies in not fearing to be weak.

Did you receive a diagnosis?
I advice that you keep a diary to track your mental state so that you can spot the signs of a psychosis.
Many people on here believe that schizophrenia is some sort of gift, and that a psychosis is 'experiencing reality as it truly is'. I firmly suggest that you disregard those claims, as the effects of schizophrenia will detach all meanings of what is real and what is not, leading to social isolation, delusional or strange beliefs, and an instable mental state.

>inb4 kike/jew/glowie/bla bla bla
I suffered a terrible psychosis last year due to me abusing drugs, and I have only just began recovering from the delusional beliefs I had. I thought I was God, I thought that all numbers were a secret code that only I could understand, though I could not, nor ever did. I believed that I could speak 'my own language', similar to what the Christians call 'speaking in tongues', however I would use numbers to connect the meanings of those words, making me look like an absolute fool. I was hostile to my family, who were pleading that I got help. I believed that they were sabotaging me, that I had powers, that this was my destiny, to bring mankind into some kind of new-age of 'nothing is real'. I walked outside into a woodland only wearing my dressing gown, because I did not care what others thought, and I had no regard for my own safety or for social norms. A pair of old people found me and followed me to make sure I was okay. I was convinced they were aliens, and I used Gematria as a mental re-assurance that it was true. I was completely delusional, and deeply depressed.
The cause of this came from me discovering that my friends who I had met online and then in person were bullying me in private conversations, and used me for laughs. I began smoking cannabis daily because I enjoyed the de-realizing effects. It was like I was in a different world.

Same author as One Punch Man, but the anime adaptation uses his actual drawing style much more closely than the OPM anime did (which was based on the manga remake of the webcomic).

The premise is that the main character, Mob, is an extremely powerful psychic but he's actually a really good kid and doesn't lean on it at all, instead trying to improve himself in any way possible (he's tiny and weak so he starts bodybuilding).
I don't want to say too much about it to avoid spoiling but it's super based.
Also, Reigen is the best and you will agree by the end of the show.

>>33746013
One Piece is literally an antidote to cynicism.
I used to work night shifts as a medic at a rehab. The kid who got me into One Piece saved my life and my soul. I had one patient who marathoned OP during his recovery and I wound up marathoning it with him.
The whole thing just RADIATES optimism harder than any other piece of media I have encountered. I was young and underpaid and working the graveyard shift.
This one patient of mine marathoned One Piece while I had him. His leg got busted up along with his addiction. We had him for longer. His leg was broken so I made him a splint and helped him walk again. The dealers had beaten him up and robbed him. I was a young medic working at a legally questionable rehab so all I could do was make him a splint and change his compression bandages each night.
All I was doing all night was responding to overdoses and suicides. This one kid who I had as a patient for like 3 weeks got to Enies Lobby with me while I just changed his bandages for a few weeks and stayed up late with him watching.
In all seriousness, the whole "DAIJOBU" that the 5th opening opens with kept me sane while I was responding to fucking suicides for 17 an hour. I know I'm not supposed to make friends with patients, but thanks, Josh. You dunno how much you helped me. I think you healed me and not the other way around.

posts.name: Peribsen
posts.com:
>>33753607

So to the first bit regarding evolution happening differently in space than on the ground, or in a cave. Ionizing radiation. There's a large amount of research already done on how radiation changes genetic properties of these fungi. Look up Chernobyl and Cryptococcus. That's the same cryptococcus neoformans that is proving to be a deadly pathogen by the way. There are other studies related to virulence increase after radiation exposure, I believe that was saccharomyces but it's another dimorphic and human pathogenic yeast so same logic applies.

Now put a species in space, where there's no atmosphere to shield against rads. The right conditions and spores could survive dessicated for an extremely long time. Meteor hits a water supply, just for example, and now you've got panspermia. Difficult odds? Sure, but not anymore than the odds of a new species just popping up out of nowhere. The clades that were mentioned for Candida Auris are odd because they showed up roughly simultaneously but had already been through enough generations to be distinct genetically.

Vancouver 1999 that was mentioned a thread or two ago is another good key in for panspermia. A large scale Cryptococcus Neoformans outbreak (largest ever for overgrowth in immunocompetent population actually) that still has no satisfactory explanation.

And sure you're going to run into resistance in the settings of concern you mentioned. But that's very different than a species just popping up en masse in areas it shouldn't be in.

I really think that consideration needs to be given to the cave origins as well. I stand by the origin point of dimorphic fungi being potentially not here originally though. They don't line up with the other fungi very well and have some odd traits. Like keying in on 95F for certain biological processes, being able to survive environments that standard dimorphic fungi can't, and even having multi stage processes to obtain energy/ATP from a living host.

posts.name: Peribsen
posts.com:
>>33753607

And on the Taforalt bit.

It's an interesting dig site and it's well known to be the oldest human dumping ground. Concurrent use is about 360K years. And the oldest genetic material in all of Africa to date comes from that exact site. And for whatever reason they decided keeping pigeons was a good idea. The caves are known for it, and pigeons are specifically known as carriers of zoonotic yeasts - candida and cryptococcus in particular.

Here's why it's so key to what I focus on. I believe that humans were actually better at immune function in the past. For some pathogens like the type of fungi we're studying, that may not have been that long ago overall.

There's are specific immune responses that get leveraged by these fungi. Primarily th-17s are the cells affected and errors there allow inflammation to go haywire. The way this plays into the dates from Taforalt is the population that resided there had high 90% rate of dental cavities. Cavities and dental issues for inflammation and decay are now being tied to candida as the catalyst (and I'll bet a couple others show up under scrutiny). Candida started the party, the rest of the germs show up to join in.

Now here's the tally. You can't have tooth decay in its accepted definition without candida present. If your immune system is functioning correctly your th-17s should be able to take care of fungal spores way before tooth decay ever sets in. However, the population at Taforalt is the earliest record of a population having a massive amount of tooth decay at around 17,500 years ago. And at a rate of 97%. There is not an earlier record of these types of cavities at this scale available, once there is I'll be revising my research appropriately.

It all boils down to firsts. Taforalt is the earliest genetic record of humans in Africa, it is the earliest record of massive dental failures thousands of years before agriculture, and there is a zoonotic disease vector present for nearly 20,000 years.

>>33742794
It would seem you would be indeed a quivk learner but also have difficulty with concentration and focus even when you know you should get to work on something and set yourself at the desk.

To better study, it would be good to, instead of procrastinating, integrate your personal research time and your study time and bounce back and forth. Trying to exclusively focus upon work for a session without the pressure of an imminent deadline may result in agitation to the point of abandoning studying altogether. So when studying alone, it might be good to spend 10 minutes on fun stuff, then switch to ten minutes of studying, then another break, etc.---making use of "breaks" but instead thinking of it as just doing both at the same time: multitasking.

You may also benefit from studying in a small group who have enough discipline not to let the study sessions get derailed.

That period of time, you may experience yourself feeling an odd, faint sense of melancholy. Ypu may dwell about problems occurring in your life and any that might be cropping up in the project. The mood may get depressive at times, but in that particular span of a few weeks or so that you've selected, you may feel a distinct motivation to push through no matter what.

You may experience it like the bounce of a ball. You fall and hit the ground, but immediately rise back up and continue going upward and onward.

You must be naturally adept at problem-solving, perhaps surprisingly anal and detail-oriented. You should have an affinity for the use of metrics and data. My recommendation would be to keep close tabs on the metrics of the development of your project and have a good sense of what anomalies are so that you can quickly formulate plans to squash them when they arise.

Also don't neglect self-care. Keep your office space very fresh and envigorating. Think about investing in scented candles or incense, noise-cancelling headphones with ocean waves ambience, plenty of coffee and water, a comfortable seat, well-ventilated workspace, and regular food.

If you have teammates you may be liable to rubbing them the wrong way or getting cross with them about something or other. Keeping yuorself personally pleased will allow you to keep work frustrations and life frustrations completely separate and allow you to better judge whatever conflicts arise in the workplace for what they are. People can be overly sensitive so you need to be prepared to be an adult and show them where they're wrong, responsibly.

•Look for posts to determine if there's an active reader, what's needed and before posting, check if they finished reading already.
•Some readers will refuse to do certain readings - respect that choice. Do not harass readers if your query is refused/skipped.
•Traders should respect that a traded read will be granted, as per an agreement of trade. Free readers have the option of picking their queries.
•Bullshit queries will get bullshit answers. Same for vague queries.
•Making an AQ (air query) by not addressing a reader, in particular, is possible but doesn't guarantee an answer.
•Avoid making the same query repeatedly and/or to different readers in a short period of time, as this may lead to more confusion.
•Provide feedback when applicable and be considerate to the reader. We're a growing community, many readers are starting and need to know what they are doing right or wrong. Let's help each other to improve.

From 78 Degrees of Wisdom, King of Wands

>...reversed indicates that person disturbed or blocked, or maybe having a bad influence on the subject. If, on the other hand, we look at the qualities in the card then reversed shows those qualities altered. Right side up the King shows us someone powerful and commanding, yet often intolerant of other people's weaknesses. Reversed we see that natural fire after it has encountered obstacles and defeats that might make a less forceful person cynical or frightened. Because he is the King of Wands he does not lose his force but becomes instead tempered, more understanding of others and at the same time harsher in his attitude to life, which no longer appears such an easy contest. Waite's formula here is very apt: ‘Good but severe, austere yet tolerant’.

The Hierophant:

>Reversed, the card means unorthodoxy, especially mental – forming original ideas. It can also, however, mean gullibility and this idea suggests another virtue of the card when it is the right way up.

Basically, she doesn't have very flattering views of you. She's not the type she's looking for and you need to move on.

posts.com:
You can express your last dreams, your attempts and ask anything about it

WBTB: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/WBTB-Tutorial
MILD: http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-mild-guide/
additional MILD info:
http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-intention-setting/
SSILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/129734-senses-initiated-lucid-dream-ssild.html
WILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/WILD-Tutorial
FILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/36683-finger-induced-lucid-dream-fild.html
DEILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/DEILD-Tutorial
CANWILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wake-initiated-lucid-dreams-wild/87710-%2A%2Acrazyinsanes-wild-tutorial-%2A%2A.html
CAT: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/CAT-Tutorial
ADA: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/113253-all-day-awareness-dild-tutorial-kingyoshi.html

Paper on natural LDs: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6290891/

Do us a favor and bump this general from time to time if you're interested

Quick reminders for beginners:
-don't forget to write your dreams down after waking up. no matter how little detail, just do it
-reality checks aren't likely to give you a LD by themselves, think of them as a stepping stool, they are not a replacement for techniques
-WBTB is mostly mandatory for most people, if you struggle with your sleep schedule then ADA is your best option
-if you're just starting out you should be doing WBTB in addition to either SSILD or MILD as those two are the easiest techniques
-while WILD and it's derivatives [FILD, DEILD and CANWILD] may sound alluring to some of you, if you cannot fall asleep within 10~20mins you're gonna have a really hard time achieving a WILD

>2.)
That's sleep paralysis followed by HH. Your body fell asleep while your mind was awake so it layered dream hallucinations on top of it.
>The only reason we have time on planet earth is due to the rotational spin of the globe
Ackshually, time exists regardless of Earth. Atoms gonna atom, and much of physics wouldn't work if time wasn't real.
>1 day is 24 hours and 1 year is 365 days through pure chance
There's nothing chance about that, unless you're talking about the Earth's position affecting those particular numbers. The numbers themselves were derived from physical measurements of how fast the sun moves across the sky from our perspective, and how many days it takes for the seasons to cycle. There's no significance to them specifically.
>How does one keep track of what year it is on another planet
For Earth years on another planet you'd use an atomic clock. It doesn't matter where in the universe you are, Caesium's still going to vibrate at the same speed. Otherwise you'd use the planet's own measurements for days/years which might be longer or shorter, but you'd still live the same absolute time (if a year was half the duration you'd live twice as many years).
The whole thing sounds like general dream nonsense to me, anion.

i then thought: "what if I don't snap out of it and wake up like i usually do, rather what if i were to speed the train of thought?"
well i managed to speed it up, and words soon became fast moving concepts, symbols and images, like fast forwarding a movie reel. there was a constant sense of direction of where the thoughts were going, and it felt like a straight road ahead, or a laser filled with thoughts that shot onwards into infinity.

it started moving so fast i couldn't control and/or understand it anymore, so when i decided to let go of it, it snapped off of the point of creation within myself. i watched the last thought i had go away into a fixed point on the horizon of the darkness of my closed eyes, and i was left in the most peaceful silence and the widest, emptiest and cleanest headspace i had in months.
when i woke up, I felt like i could keep this clear headspace if i focused on maintaining all mental conditions like they were back then, but unfortunately the internal chatter returned in 30 minutes of so when i opened my laptop to catch up on some emails.

anybody experienced something similar before, or tried to produce something similar?
or anyone has some resources i could look into?

>>33686943
1. Get on a good sleep schedule, 8 hours a night.
2. When you awake from a dream, lay still and do not move. Focus all your energy on remembering every detail of the dream.
3. Write down the dreams in a way you feel comfortable that will allow you to identify common themes.
4. Pay attention to these commons themes and try to find waking similarities to them.
5. Develop reality checks based off of those similarities. Make it become second nature/muscle memory to constantly check to see if you're dreaming based off of those dream/reality similarities.
6. You will begin to notice these things in your dreams and will start to question if you are dreaming while you are in fact dreaming.
7. Once you realize you are fully conscious while you are dreaming, remain calm. Spin in place and perform simple tasks with your mind to solidify your lucidity in your dream. (Turn lights off and on, move small objects, try to read text or clocks, etc)
8. Remain calm. Spin in place again if you have to. Later you can use this practice to change your dream setting.
9. Go slowly. Do not immediately try to materialize a girl to have sex with or fly or whatever your wildest fantasy you want to act out is. Be consistent with all steps even after you begin to frequently achieve lucidity.
10. Learn to flow with the dreams while controlling them with subtlety. Enjoy them, learn from them. Learn from the people you can speak with. Learn ways to go further, deeper. Don't overthink or over analyze.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33687689
>how long does all this take?
That depends entirely on your commitment to keeping a dream journal. A lot of people, especially 99% of the total faggots that frequent /x/ now, will say this is gay and stupid. These people have no, do not and will never become lucid in a dream. The dream journal is possibly the most important practice to keep to become a consistent lucid dreamer. It's perhaps more important than maintaining a good sleep schedule to allow your brain to get into those good sleep cycles. You absolutely must focus and remember your dreams in as much detail as you can in order to find the common themes and instances that can help you trigger reality checks which will result in you becoming lucid.
You can get an app, or just keep a notebook next to your bed; whatever.
>what do i write down?
First, just focus on the dream. The smallest amount of movement or other thoughts will fire neurons in your brain and immediately make you start forgetting the dream. Even opening your eyes while lying still is enough to make your brain fire and forget. Just lay still and replay the dream and burn it into your memory. As much detail as possible. Then, write it down. It will take some time to build up a good library of dreams before you can start noticing common themes and weird instances you can use as trigger points for reality checks.

>What are your beliefs about extraterrestrial life?

Simple extraterrestrial life such as algaes, planktons, amoebas, maybe even simple surface vegetation, is probably very common- maybe even abundant. I wouldn't be surprised if such organisms were found in subterranean Mars, underneath the ice of Europa, and in the atmosphere of Venus. Life seems to be extremely persistent, adaptable, and essentially impossible to permanently eliminate once conceived.
I'm expecting complex extraterrestrial life (things with bones) to be far less common, but not exactly rare. Animals might be a "once per solar system" kind of occurrence: only propagating on the most consistent climate-controlled kind of "goldilocks" planet in a given system. I don't agree with speculative biologists. At all. Alien animals will most likely be very similar to what we've already witnessed with Earth animals. It's like how Dinosaurs all evolved from a different common ancestor to Mammals, but despite this Dinosaurs and Mammals still developed into very similar creatures because they still ultimately needed to do and survive the same conditions and some designs are just "the meta".

Very minor happening but I’ll keep it short and sweet

>finish closing down restaurant at end of a shift with friend/roommate
>he drives back to house and I ride my bicycle
>city’s laid out so that it’s often faster to bike than to drive, even with no traffic in the middle of the night like it was then
>i get home first and leave my bike propped up after entering, and using my phone’s flashlight, I do a quick sweep of each room of the house to check for spooky burglars or intruders
>i don’t turn on any lights and it is fully dark apart from my phone and my bike light which is still on
>make a loop of house which means 1st living room, 2nd living room, bedrooms, kitchen, back room, then back thru kitchen to get back to 1st living room, in that order
>while i am coming back through the kitchen, about five steps away from being back in the doorway of the 1st living room, I hear the distinct flicking sound of our lamp’s switch
>I jump a little bit because spooked, and then make it to the doorway to look into the 1st living room to see our lamp now on
>don’t know how long I stood staring at the lamp but probably less than 30 second later, my roommate pulls into the driveway and less than a minute from then he enters the front door
>I’m still standing there staring and spooked and i explain it to him
>we conclude that it was weird

it is a famously “haunted” city, and that is the closest I came to experiencing it as far as I can tell. Thanks for reading my uneventful but honest-as-possible tale

They're all about fighting the hedonic treadmill. It's all about living a good stimulus so often that you get fed up on it, you don't want it anymore.
My personal example is tacos, specifically Arabian tacos, they were my favorite food, but only had enough to buy them once per month as a luxury. I was full of anticipation for that day and when it came it was like a party.
But then I became rich, so the first thing I did was buying them daily. Even, finding ways to buy a bunch and store them and bring them back to the "recently made" flavor.
How much did that last?
Two weeks.
After two weeks of Arabian tacos daily I didn't want them anymore, and the worst part was I had the fridge full of them, so I was FORCED to eat them because I couldn't bring myself to just throw them away. I had to take a break from them for like a year to eat one again.
THAT's the hedonic treadmill, but it also works in reverse, if you keep doing something you hate you can flip it and feel its inverse.
That's all you need to know about cold showers, they're about feeling something terrible over and over, until the treadmill hits and you enjoy them, and you enjoy them more and more...
In fact, if you don't feel terrible when you take a cold shower, nothing happens, up the coldness or something, it needs to feel bad, and the worse it feels the better the reward.
Cold showers are an advanced version of wearing uncomfortable shoes to feel the relief of taking them off.

>>33728020
>I think that every religion big and small has a lot of overlap, it's a pipe dream of mine to travel the world and compare all world religions. I think because they have similar roles in their respective pantheon and are more or less major deities in their pantheon that they could be the same.
I think that's partially true. I've come to understand it that a lot of the entities we interact with when communing with a deity tend to be more like 'titles', for lack of a better terminology, than individuals. Most gods tend to embody fundamental concepts and are woven into an egregor of persona by the observations of man, but that's simply all that we're observing, not necessarily the totality of the the entity we're interacting with. So that's to say, these entities we commune with are made up of 'multiple' deities from various mythologies /pantheons because the inherent nature of what we've collectively deified is a specific facet of them. That said, I suspect there's an affinity you could try and quantify an entity with as 'more Zerus than Ares' or perhaps 'definitively Odin' if an entity primarily (but not entirely) embraces that aspect of themselves. When viewed in this light, it also helps reconcile a lot of the seemingly schizophrenic behavior they exhibit in mythologies because there's more than one entity embodying that aspect in the story and the nature of conflating the deified title with the essence of being tends to lead to the appearance of a somewhat schizophrenic-looking behavior pattern. I also suspect many of them feel very misunderstood by this 'typecasting', but that likely varies on an individual basis. As a disclaimer, this is my current working understanding after a lot of work with a lot of 'gods' but ultimately still filtering through my body's perception so not everything may be perfect.

posts.sub: A simple convincing explaination ehy the earth is flat
posts.com:
Disclaimer: I do not actually believe the earth is flat (or round for that matter) as I can't PROVE what shape the earth is. But what I can do is ask questions.

Ok, so here it is: Suppose some dude had a private jet with an infinite amount of fuel. Suppose he took of and quickly reached an altitude of 200 meters above the ground. Then he engaged autopilot and left the computer stabilize the plane at a vertical speed of exactly zero (meaning the plane should not be flying towards the ground or away from it). Then he left the autopilot on for like 10 hours and went to sleep. If the earth was a globe, when he woke up, he should see that the altitude of the plane was now orders of magnitude higher than 200 meters, even though the vertical speed had been zero all this time. (Why? Well, the plane was flying in a straight line, but since the earth is a globe the trajectory of any straight line starting at any given point on the globe, eventually has to leave the atmosphere and pierce out into space and beyond).

Obviously this does not sound like reality, intercontinental flights do not have to make constant vertical axis tilt adjusments just to keep a steady altitude.

Conclusion? You tell me. I think there is enough evidence already that either
a) the Earth is not a globe
Or
b) the Earth is MUCH bigger than we are taught.
Of course there could be other possible explanations which I personally am not smart enough to think up.
In any case, I am not here to preach anything, but this thought experiment is pretty funny in itself.

>>33739540
Say a fish was swimming at a 45 degree angle towards the surface. Why doesn't it continue going upwards once it exists the water?

A plane doesn't just go in a fixed 3D direction. It is constantly affected by gravity, and it "surfs" the air. And needs a certain amount of air pressure to do so. The more it is angled "away' from the Earth, the harder it is to fly in that direction.

What goes into affecting a plane's flight path is gravity, air pressure, the wing and tail flap position, and the engine power.
Gravity and air pressure naturally follow the earths curvature. The pilot only controls the flaps and the engine power. And keeping those constant, you'll just be like a fish trying to swim out of the water.

Tldr. gravity, and air pressure differences prevent any normal plane from traveling at a significant height, or at a signification angle form the earth.
